metadata.title: Can you land your first data science job without having a MOOC certificate? | by Srishti Singh | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Can you land your first data science job without having a MOOC certificate?
metadata.description: Here's how I got my first data science internship turned into a fulltime job without doing any paid courses and learned data science/ML/NLP while getting paid for it.

all_paragraphs: I am a CS graduate (class of 2019). By the end of my second year in college, I started losing interest in web development, which led me to explore other computer science fields, later in which I can possibly work on for my final year thesis, and do further research for my Masters. And all of this led me to AI/ML/DL/DS, etc.

Fast forward to August 2018, 7th semester in college, the one in which I had to write my final year thesis. I ended up writing a research paper on browser extensions. Not ML, Not DL, Nothing even remotely related to data science or Python. I still don’t know how it got selected for a publication.

Later in May 2019, just 2 months before my convocation ceremony, I started panicking that I’ve no job offer, no internship, nothing at all to show for my “hard work” done in the last 4 years of college. Among all this chaos and uncertainty, I was sure about one thing — I had to get into data science, no matter what. Why? Because that’s the bar I set for myself to measure my self-worth (I know, for all the wrong reasons).
Now how to get into data science?

Googled the exact same thing, and read articles after articles, Medium posts, Quora answers, Reddit threads, watched tonnes of Youtube videos, joined random Slack communities, and Whatsapp groups, my first was this slack group MIT Deep Learning courses created by Lex Fridman. Discovering that slack community was nothing less than a eureka moment for me. [A lot of these research were done during my final year in college, so they’re not the most updated]
Here are some key recommendations from all that browsing and googling:

Among all of these findings, Siraj Raval “ Learn Data Science in 3 months” is actually a good roadmap for topics to be covered when learning data science. But here’s the gist of all this research, it’ll take a solid 3 months period of dedicated studying, following online courses, doing the capstone project, learning Maths, and what not to get to your foot into the field.

Now this made me realize that I can’t really keep up with this track. Focusing on something for 3 months straight that may or may not result in success is not something I was willing to put my efforts into, why? because I was like, “what did I learn all these years in my 4 years of college!?”
To my own knowledge, I had done a lot of projects (outside coursework), and how come none of those is useful now, just to get an entry-level job related to CS?

I decided, instead of doing online courses, what if I just apply for a data science internship, and based on my other projects, even though irrelevant, they might give me a chance. And even if they don't, the assignments/projects given by them during the selection process will be really useful for the next application. And if I’m unable to do any of those projects, I’ll get back to the traditional path, i.e. to do the courses first.
And this single idea is what the whole post is about!

I polished my resume, updated my Github with some college projects, even held up some live websites(a fully functional e-commerce site selling books), etc., and started applying to every internship remotely related to data science, basically anything with Data+Python. [mainly through Internshala]

To my surprise, I started getting responses from each of them. They were giving me assignments (coding projects), and I started doing those. One of the first ones was, reading-writing and tagging Dicom files using Pydicom. I had no CLUE what Dicom or Pydicom was. But I googled, completed the assignment. They didn't offer me the internship but asked if I can contribute to their open source project. I said Yes immediately.

Like that, I had applied to some 5 internships simultaneously and was getting assignment tasks from all of them. But after completing the first 2–3 rounds of their assignments, I had to reject 3 of them to focus on the 2 important ones:

I then went lazy with the first option (even though C++ is my to-date favorite language to code in) and got rejected. The selection rounds of the second option went like this: the first assignment to solve some regex problem in Python (to test my Python skills). Now, having little to no knowledge of Python, I started with learning some basic syntax with W3 schools, and later with the help of StackOverflow and some intensive googling, I was done with this assignment in 2 days.
Like that, after 4 rounds of assignments and some phone interviews (with really weird negotiations), they finally gave me the offer!
Factors involved in this success story: efforts + luck
